abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Economic Management
            Credit is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as satisfactory.
            The key lessons learned include: A macroeconomic adjustment
            program dealing with policy reforms and administrative
            restructuring at the central levels of Government should not
            be combined with a grassroots operation in widely dispersed
            rural areas. These usually require intensive supervision and
            likely some technical and operational support, which is
            difficult to accommodate within the structure of an
            adjustment operation. Another approach may be to arrange
            with one of the resident bilateral donors to provide this
            type of assistance under a cofinancing agreement. Careful
            attention should be paid to the design of progress and
            output monitoring indicators, to ensure that there is a
            clear relationship between the inputs provided under the
            project and the expected output. That was not always the
            case in this project. For example, the impact of the
            mandated recruitment of additional primary school teachers
            on primary school enrollment ratios could have been offset
            by other factors, leading to a constant ratio. The correct
            assessment of the impact would require estimates holding
            other influences constant.
